ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Rotations are required, but there is a good reason for this. Rotations allow you to try different labs so you can find a good fit. Since one rotation has to be an "off" rotation, you have the chance to experience a different field. The amount of time you spend depends a lot on the professor, and through rotations you can see if the work schedule of the lab fits with want you want.
Rotation is necessary for finding a good thesis lab.
Essential way to tour labs to determine what work you would like to do.
It's a lab rotation. It depends a lot on the lab in question but you do get a good feel for the lab work and environment.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I learned different techniques through rotations and had my own project in both of my rotations so far. Although the rotation project most likely won't be the thesis project, I can get an idea of lab dynamics and also different types of research done in the lab.
I found the lab that I want to work in during my rotation.
Rotations have been extremely useful in helping me broaden my skills and knowledge in various biochemistry techniques.
Fairly self-explanatory. I got a good idea of what it would be like to work in both labs.
